characters: NEW YORK, NORTH ATLANTIC OCEAN, SOUTH ATLANTIC OCEAN,
CHINA, INDIA, INDIAN OCEAN, SINGAPORE, AUSTRALIA
WOMAN IN RED FLOWER DRESS WOMAN IN BLUE DRESS

dialogues.speaker: A PORTRAIT
dialogues.text: of a modern ENGLISH LORD. The brass placard reads: “Lord Rupert Calthorpe-Cavendish-Gore.” REVEAL we're in the lobby of an ostentatious hotel. It’s deserted except for TWO CLERKS at the front desk. It is the middle of the night and RAINING HEAVILY outside.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: The revolving doors start to swing as TWO CHILDREN (NICK 8, ASTRID 8) and TWO CHINESE WOMEN, ELEANOR and FELICITY YOUNG (30s) enter. They’re DRIPPING WET, dragging their soaked luggage behind them. Nick SLIDES his feet around the polished floor, leaving a MUDDY CIRCLE in his wake. The clerks look horrified. Eleanor makes her way to the front desk, while complaining to Felicity about having to walk in the bad weather.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (in Cantonese; subtitled) If you didn’t make us walk, we wouldn’t be soaked. Felicity grabs the children by the hand and follows Eleanor to the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: May I help you? This is the Calthorpe, a private hotel -- (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor goes to the desk and replies in PERFECT ENGLISH - her pronunciation is BRITISH, with a lilt unique to upper crust Chinese from former British colonies. (NOTE: The specific accents of our players are important character details, indications of their background, education, and socioeconomic status.)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’m Mrs. Eleanor Young. I have a reservation. The Lancaster suite. (sees his name tag) We spoke on the phone when I confirmed yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Sorry, don’t seem to have your reservation. Clerk #2 surreptitiously presses a BUTTON under the counter. Eleanor and Felicity exchange glances. Felicity rolls her eyes, sensing what’s going on. REGINALD ORMSBY (50s, pompous) pops out of a door behind the front desk and the clerks move aside.

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Good evening. I’m Reginald Ormsby, hotel manager. Is there a problem?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’m Mrs. Eleanor Young. My family and I would like to be shown to our suite. We’ve had a long flight. Ormsby takes in Eleanor et al, makes a snap judgment.

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: We’re fully booked, madam. You must have made a mistake. I’m sure you and your lovely family can find other accommodations. May I suggest you explore Chinatown?

dialogues.speaker: FELICITY
dialogues.text: (in Cantonese; subtitled; mutters) You can explore Hell. You dog turd. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Please, may I use your phone to call my husband? It’s the least you can do. Eleanor levels a glare at Ormsby, who looks at her with a tight smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAIN POURS on the children and Felicity as they watch Eleanor in a PHONE BOOTH. “THE CALTHORPE” sign casts a glow over them. We don’t know what she’s saying, but we hear Eleanor angrily speaking on the pone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eleanor bursts through the front door with her family right behind her. Eleanor approaches the front desk again. Ormsby is not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Young! I must ask you to leave, or I’ll have to call the police.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Please, go right ahead. Ormsby is taken aback. He moves to stop her when the elevator DINGS and OPENS and an ELDERLY MAN IN A SILK ROBE AND SLIPPERS comes out -- LORD CALTHORPE, the same man in the opening portrait and owner of the hotel. Ormsby snaps to.

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Lord Calthorpe! My apologies for this disturbance -- Lord Calthorpe ignores Ormsby and beelines for Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CALTHORPE
dialogues.text: Eleanor! I just got off the phone with your husband. Lord Calthorpe kisses Eleanor on the cheek, and snaps at the clerks.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CALTHORPE
dialogues.text: Get the Lancaster suite ready. Now. Ormsby reacts, confused. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: Surely you’re joking, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CALTHORPE
dialogues.text: I assure you, I’m not. As of this evening, my family’s long history as custodians of the Calthorpe is ended. I am selling the hotel to my dear friends, the Young family of Singapore. Ormsby looks at Eleanor, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CALTHORPE
dialogues.text: Meet the new lady of the house, Eleanor Young. (to Eleanor) Join me for a toast.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: We'd be delighted. (turns to address Ormsby ) Do get a mop. The floor’s wet. Eleanor winks at Nick, who grins and looks back at Ormsby.

dialogues.speaker: ORMSBY
dialogues.text: (to Clerk #1) Get a mop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring across a table is RACHEL CHU (29, Chinese- American, beautiful, sharp). She exudes confidence. PULL BACK to reveal a pile of chips in front of her. We see someone else’s hand checking the cards they’ve been dealt: 2 KINGS, 2 NINES, and a JACK. They’re in the middle of a five card draw poker game. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the CAMERA TILTS UP we see CURTIS (late 20s, T.A., white) is the player sitting across from Rachel. He stares at her over his black-rimmed glasses, trying to read her. She stares back, revealing nothing. Rachel pushes the pile of chips to the center of the poker table.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m all in. Curtis has FIVE CHIPS left. He checks his cards again, then FOLDS.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Fold. Rachel flips over her cards. She’s got nothing.

dialogues.speaker: CURTIS
dialogues.text: Nothing! (as Rachel laughs) This whole time you had nothing. The lights come up and we see A ROOM FULL OF PEOPLE CLAP AND TITTER. REVEAL we’re in: AN AUDITORIUM CLASSROOM with UNDERGRAD STUDENTS. The poker table onstage is being shown on two LARGE FLATSCREENS so the students can follow the action. Rachel takes the lectern. “Game Theory 290” appears on the side screens.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: All right, so, how did I beat T.A. Curtis so very, very badly? Well, I know for a fact that Curtis is cheap. The students all smile and laugh, totally engaged.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So, he’s not playing using logic or math, but using his psychology. Our brains so hate the idea of losing something that’s valuable to us, that we abandon all rational thought and make some really poor decisions. So Curtis wasn’t playing to win. He was playing not to lose. (to Curtis; tosses him a chip) Here. Put it towards a haircut. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class LAUGHS. Curtis takes the $10 with a BANDAGED HAND.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: All right, that’s it for today. Don’t forget your essays on conditional probability are due next week -- As students file out, NICK walks in and smiles lasciviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Rachel share a STICKY TOFFEE PUDDING like an old married couple.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (digging in) Yes!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You know what, you can order your own.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (taking a bite; chewing) Mm, I’m okay with coffee. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, you always say that, and then you end up eating all my dessert. Nick takes a huge bite.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (mouth full) I don’t know what you’re talking about? ‘Cause I have, like, a tiny bit. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Okay. (to waiter) Can we have one more of these, please. (chuckling) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: So, what about us taking an adventure east?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You wanna get pork buns in the East Village. That’s what it is, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I was actually thinking of further east.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Like Queens.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Like Singapore? For spring break? (off Rachel) Colin's wedding. We’ve been dating for over a year now, and I think it’s about time people met my beautiful girlfriend. Come on, I’m Colin’s best man. Don’t you wanna see where I grew up? Meet my family, my Ah Ma? And meet up with that strange college roommate of yours.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Peik Lin.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm. Peik Lin.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: She has been begging me to come visit her, you know?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The universe has spoken. It wants you over there. Come to Singapore. I want the whole island to meet the brilliant Rachel Chu. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Aw. A woman sitting at a booth behind them watches Rachel and Nick, interested in their every move. She gets up and walks past them with her cell phone and snaps a photo as she passes in front of them. She immediately starts

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF TEXTS
dialogues.text: RadiolAsia: OMG. You’ll never believe who I saw. Girl: WHO? RadiolAsia e-mails the picture of Rachel and Nick. Girl: Is that NICK YOUNG? RadiolAsia: Yes. Girl: Who’s the girl? RadiolAsia: Said her name was Rachel Chu. Group TEXT with photo: Who IS this girl? Nick and Rachel’s picture is sent out all over Social Media. They Google Rachel Chu. TEXT: Wah, so many Rachel Chu’s lah We see photos of searches matching Rachel Chu. TEXT: Did you try Choo? Or Chiu? Or Chew? Or Zhu? TEXT: OMFG! yah, which one? Ask the Twins? Twin #1 TEXT: Found her! Twin #2 TEXT: Found her? TEXT: Rachel Chu TEXT: Is there a ring? TEXT: Looks ABC

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: TEXT: u joking? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TEXT: Hate her!!!! TEXT: Be serious TEXT: Better not TEXT: No thanks RadiolAsia: He’s bringing her to the wedding!

dialogues.speaker: TEXT
dialogues.text: Alamak!!!

dialogues.speaker: SRSLY
dialogues.text: Kantang!!! Drama! No way!

dialogues.speaker: OMFG
dialogues.text: So not NOOOOO Does Amanda know?

dialogues.speaker: NO WAY
dialogues.text: Why her!

dialogues.speaker: WIF
dialogues.text: serious

dialogues.speaker: LOSER
dialogues.text: ew no walao!! Basic AF Like Really?? OK and?? baiiiii Does his Mother know?  10.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. PHILLIP AND ELEANOR’S HOUSE (SINGAPORE) - MORNING ELEANOR reads a Bible verse aloud to a group of ladies.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: ‘If then you have been raised with Christ, seek the things that are above, where Christ is seated at the right hand of God.’ It's been twenty years since we’ve seen Eleanor, but she looks amazing. She sits with FOUR FABULOUSLY DRESSED, BEJEWELED WOMEN: JACQUELINE LING (50s), ALIX YOUNG (50s), NADINE (30s), AND LORENA (40s). Uniformed MAIDS serve tea and “kuih,” local cakes.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: ‘Set your minds on things that are above, not on things that are on Earth.’ Eleanor’s interrupted by BUZZING. She looks disapproving as Alix and Jacqueline check their messages. These matriarchs speak with UPPER-CRUST CHINESE SINGAPOREAN ACCENTS (perfect grammar with local flourishes). Jacqueline reacts, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: Eleanor, is Nicki bringing a girl to Colin’s wedding? My Amanda heard it from her friend, Francesca... Eleanor is surprised, but tries not to let on.

dialogues.speaker: ALIX
dialogues.text: (looking at phone) Eddie says her name is Rachel Chu?

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Oh! I thought that Nick was coming alone. Did you know he had a girlfriend? All eyes are on Eleanor who covers, not wanting to get into the details. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Nick dates many girls. It’s hard to keep track.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: Amanda knows everyone and she has never heard of her.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Rachel Chu. Or maybe she’s from the Taiwan plastics Chu family?

dialogues.speaker: ALIX
dialogues.text: (low; conspiratorial) If you want, I have a private investigator. Very discreet --

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (interrupting) I think we should return to the word of God. Alix? The women reluctantly return to their Bibles.

dialogues.speaker: ALIX
dialogues.text: Ephesians. Chapter six, verse four. ‘Bring up your children in the discipline and instruction of the Lord.’ (can’t help herself) Oh, I do hope she’s a good, Christian girl.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: Well, if he’s bringing her home, it must be serious.

dialogues.speaker: NADINE
dialogues.text: Exactly. The women all look at Eleanor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESUME Rachel and Nick. Nick’s phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s my mum. Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mm, go ahead. Rachel is about to dig into pudding #2. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Rachel) All right. Save me some of that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Nick gets up to take the call away from the counter.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hey, Mum, everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Does something have to wrong for me to call?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, usually.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ha, ha, ha. Very funny. INT. PHILLIP AND ELEANOR’S HOUSE (SINGAPORE) - DAY Eleanor is on her phone standing away from her Bible group. Keeps her voice low, casual. INTERCUT AS NECESSARY with Nick and Eleanor talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Are you bringing the girl you’re seeing to Colin's wedding?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (confused) Hmm. We were literally just talking about that. How could you know?

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Everybody knows. Nick sees Celine (the only other Asian in the restaurant) leaving through a revolving door.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Radio One Asia. Eleanor notices the other women trying to eavesdrop. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (to ladies) Move on to Corinthians, I’1l catch up.

dialogues.speaker: ALIX
dialogues.text: Ah, yes.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (back to phone; low) We're looking forward to having you home. And your room is all ready... for you. Nick hears this, gets the implication.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mom. But Rachel and I will be staying together. Eleanor is disappointed, makes another attempt:

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I see. Well, I’m having the house redone. And it’s not ready for guests. If Rachel comes, I think she might be more comfortable staying somewhere else? Nick returns to the counter, to see the second sticky toffee pudding is gone, except for a TINY PIECE.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: All right. Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I saved you a piece.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You did, did you? A very small piece at that. Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: How’s your mom? Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Mm. Couldn’t be better. Rachel kisses nick.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (pre-lap) Hey, Mom, this one’s kind of cute.  14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel looks at her reflection in a mirror as she holds a blue and white dress to her body. Her mother, KERRY (50s, real estate agent, Chico chic), shakes her head. Kerry has a slight Chinese immigrant accent.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: No! No! No! No! You can’t wear that to meet Nick’s Ah Ma. Blue and white is for Chinese funerals. Now this, this symbolizes good fortune and fertility. Kerry holds up a conservative RED dress.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Great! I was really going for that ‘lucky baby-maker’ vibe.

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: Hey! You are the one who asked for my help picking out a dress to meet Nick’s family.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It’s only ‘cause I hardly know anything about them. Every time I bring them up Nick changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s embarrassed. Maybe his parents are poor, and he has to send them money. That’s what all good Chinese children do. Rachel chuckles and they keep searching for the right dress.

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: Oh, you are going to have a wonderful time. You've always wanted to go to Asia and who knows, if all goes well in Singapore, you might just come back with a souvenir.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mom, stop! Nick and I haven’t even talked about that. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, his parents can’t not like me, right? Kerry has a sour look on her face and turns away to begin rummaging through a clothes rack.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What was that look? I saw that.

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: Nothing. It’s just, Nick bringing a girl all the way there to meet them can mean a lot to these overseas families. Eh, they’re different from us.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: How are they different? They’re Chinese, I’m Chinese. I’m so Chinese, I’m an economics professor with lactose intolerance.

dialogues.speaker: KERRY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you grew up here. (in Mandarin; subtitled) Ni kan qilai shi huaren, ni jiang de shi zhongwen. kKeshi zheli he zheli... [Your face is Chinese. You speak Chinese. But here... (points to Rachel’s head and mouth) -.. and here... (in English) You're different. But wearing a lucky color will make a good first impression.

dialogues.speaker: CURBSIDE
dialogues.text: Amid the hectic bustle, Nick and Rachel exit a taxi. An airport sign behind them reads: Kuwait Airways, Pacific Asian Airlines, Qatar Airways, Malaysian Airlines, Cathay Pacific.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Attention, the white zone is for passenger loading and unloadings only. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elegant approaches 16.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay, game plan. Check our bags, get through security, and then we could eat one of the three homemade Tupperware meals my mom packed for us.

dialogues.speaker: PACIFIC ASEAN AIRLINES FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: , flanked by TWO PORTERS with luggage carts.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Mr. Young, Ms. Chu. We’ll take your bags and get you checked into first class.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Great. Rachel looks confused as the porters take their bags.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh. No, there's a mistake. We're not first class. We’re economy people.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: This way, please. Nick puts a hand in the small of her back:

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Just go with it. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah, they'll be fine. Just leave them there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLIGHT ATTENDANT #2 pulls back a gold, silk curtain revealing a luxurious part of the plane that looks more like a hotel. Another attendant serves them champagne.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Welcome aboard, Mr. Young, Ms. Chu. Here’s the way to your private suite. And some champagne. They walk up to a full bar where champagne is poured for them. Rachel turns to Nick like “what’s going on?” (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to serving flight attendant) Thank you. Rachel is blown away to see the leather armchairs, two huge flatscreen TVs, even a full-length wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: You're welcome. After takeoff, would you like to enjoy the lounge chairs or should we convert your suite into a bedroom? Rachel clobbers Nick with a bag to keep him from responding.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Uh, we’re good. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Enjoy. Nick looks to Rachel. The Flight Attendant leaves. As Nick settles in, Rachel looks at the complimentary pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nick. We can’t afford this. These pajamas are fancier than any of my real clothes.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hmm? My family has business with the airline. The tickets, they’re a perk. Rachel senses there’s more to this. Pursues it:

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What kind of business?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Real estate, investment, other things. Nothing interesting. (reading menu) Dim sum.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So your family is, like, rich? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Uh, we’re comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: That is exactly what a super rich person would say. It’s not a big deal, obviously. I just think it’s kind of weird that I had no idea. I mean, you have a Jamba Juice card, you use my Netflix password. You play basketball at that Y that kind of smells. Nick sees Rachel is a little thrown.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I really like that place, thank you very much. And yes, my family has money, but I’ve always thought of it as theirs. Not mine.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I get that. But I’m going all the way over there to meet them... Kind of just wanna know what I’m getting into. And, you know, they’re your family.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well... My family is much like anybody else’s. There’s half of them that you love and respect, and then there’s the other half.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Which half am I meeting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HERO faces off against a VILLAIN. In the b.g., a BUXOM HEROINE is chained to a wall. The Hero and villain launch into a fast-paced, stylistic KUNG-FU FIGHT. The Hero wins and sets free the Heroine, who clutches him.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, there’s my cousin Alistair, based in Taiwan, works in movies. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Sitting on movie set is ALISTAIR CHENG (30s, sunglasses, dapper). The empty chair next to him has the name KITTY PONG on the back.

dialogues.speaker: MALE DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: And cut!

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He’s dating Kitty Pong, an actress.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Kitty. Buxom Heroine KITTY PONG (20s, DD implants) runs into the arms of Alistair. She speaks with a GIRLY TAIWANESE ACCENT.

dialogues.speaker: KITTY
dialogues.text: Alistair. You like it? I was feeling very... very the emotions. Can you feel it? Kitty grabs his hand and places it forcefully on her boob.

dialogues.speaker: ALISTAIR
dialogues.text: Oh, I can feel all of you. And all of me. Alistair grabs Kitty’s left thigh and yanks it up onto his hip. The DIRECTOR and Hero/Actor have an aside. On the back of the chair “TAIPEI TIGER 2.”

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE HERO
dialogues.text: (in Mandarin; subtitled) Ta zhen de lan toule. Keyi huan ren ma? [She’s terrible. Can we get someone else?]

dialogues.speaker: MALE DIRECTORT
dialogues.text: (in Mandarin; subtitled) Zhe bu xi ta nanpengyou dou zhidao. Ni neng shuo huan ren ma. [He’s financing the whole movie. You tell him his girlfriend sucks. ] They look on as Alistair and Kitty make out.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Rachel continue their conversation.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay, and what about your cousin Eddie? You don’t ever talk about him.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, Eddie is a big finance guy in Hong Kong. A real family man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, his wife FIONA CHENG (30s, Hong Kong Chinese, in a simple but elegant dress), and their three sons (all under 8 and wearing matching Gucci outfits) are frozen in “natural” poses -- Eddie and Fiona “laugh” as their boys “play” with wooden airplanes that look more like props than toys -- as photographer RUSSELL WONG takes their portrait. Behind them, wide, floor-to-ceiling windows frame a panoramic view of Hong Kong.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: EDDIE CHENG (30s, intense investment banker), ASTRID (30s, gorgeous, elegant).

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL WONG
dialogues.text: You know if you move, it will look more natural.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, this way you get our optimal angles.

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL WONG
dialogues.text: Uh, then we’re done. As Russell wraps up, Eddie scurries over, all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Russell, thank you so much. It’s an honor to be photographed by you.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: (to kids) Good job, guys. (to nannies) Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RUSSELL WONG
dialogues.text: My pleasure. People will love it in the next Hong Kong Vogue.

dialogues.speaker: NANNY
dialogues.text: (to kids) Give me that. You have to take a bath now.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: Thank you, Russell. Eddie beams, but the moment Russell and his ASSISTANTS exit, Eddie loses his smile. Turns on his wife, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hong Kong Vogue? I knew it. Your dress is a disaster. If you wore a Bottega gown, like I told you to, we'd be in the American Vogue.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: You can wear that gown to Hell, Eddie. Fiona walks off as the children jump into 2 TOY BENTLEYS and start chasing their beleaguered NANNIES...

dialogues.speaker: NANNY
dialogues.text: (to kids) Stop!

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Then there’s Astrid.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I remember Astrid. She’s like who I wanna be when I grow up.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Astrid is awesome. And she’s probably the only one I’m actually close with. And she’s really grounded and down to earth once you get to know her.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ASTRID (30s), striking, enters a LUXE HIGH-END BOUTIQUE where WEALTHY FEMALE CUSTOMERS look over FINE JEWELRY.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not only did she graduate top of her class at Oxford, start multiple charities and is a fashion icon, Astrid has the biggest heart of any of my cousins. Astrid sees a LITTLE GIRL, the daughter of a customer, holding a TINY, STUFFED BUNNY with a YARN BOW as she tugs on her mother’s sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Mummy? See what I made for bunny -- But her mother waves her away, busy looking over baubles with her friend. LITTLE GIRL’S MOTHER No, not now, not now. But the customers, including the Little Girl’s mother, soon notice Astrid and sneak looks and whisper to one another about her. Astrid walks by them and goes to the Little Girl, much to her mother’s surprise.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: (bends down; to Girl) Hi, I’m Astrid. What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Vita.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: (re: bunny) And who's this?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Bun-Bun.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Well, I think Bun-Bun looks very dashing with his bow. You have a good eye.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE GIRL
dialogues.text: Thank you. The Little Girl BEAMS, delighted. The girl’s MOTHER lights up, proud. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The JEWELER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: JEWELER
dialogues.text: Ms. Leong, right this way.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: It's very nice to meet you both. The patrons watch Astrid and the Jeweler disappear through a hallway into a restricted area...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a private room reserved for elite clientele. An ASSISTANT brings Astrid tea in a tiny antique cup as she surveys A STUNNING SELECTION OF OVER-THE-TOP JEWELRY.

dialogues.speaker: JEWELER
dialogues.text: These are all brand new from Antwerp. You’re the first person I’ve shown them to. Astrid is unimpressed. Then she sees in ANOTHER DISPLAY CASE an understated pair of pearl drop earrings. She looks at them, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: What are those? The Jeweler smiles, approving of Astrid’s taste. He takes the earrings out so she can get a closer look.

dialogues.speaker: JEWELER
dialogues.text: Those. Those are very special. Burmese pearl drop earrings. Set with emeralds, and rare pigeon- blood-red rubies. They were worn by Queen Supayalat at her self- anointed coronation in 1878. The assistant brings the earrings to Astrid. She picks them up to look closer, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: JEWELER
dialogues.text: Having you wear one of my pieces is better publicity than I can buy. I’11 let them go at cost. (beat) One point two million. Astrid gives a subtle nod.  24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane is now in the air and Nick and Rachel’s suite has been converted into a bedroom. They wear the complimentary pajamas as they lie in bed, continuing their conversation about Nick’s family.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: So, if you have all this family there, why are we staying in a hotel? Aren’t good Chinese sons supposed to stay with their parents?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, because A) I’m not that good a son, and B) I just want you to myself, just for a bit. That okay?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay. Rachel smiles and kisses Nick. He rolls on top of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane flies across the South China Sea into the sunset, heading for a SHINING JEWEL at the tip of the Malaysian Peninsula.

dialogues.speaker: CHINA, INDIA, INDIAN OCEAN, SINGAPORE, AUSTRALIA
dialogues.text: We ZOOM IN ON SINGAPORE --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Rachel emerge with other TRAVELERS, pushing luggage carts as they emerge from customs. Rachel looks around the shiny arrival hall in wonderment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I can’t believe this airport has a butterfly garden and a movie theater. JFK is just salmonella and despair.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nick!!! Nick!!! Through the crowd runs a willowy, young woman, ARAMINTA (20s) clutching BALLOONS, rushing up to meet them. She throttles Nick, wrapping her legs tightly around his waist. Behind her is a ruggedly handsome man, COLIN (30s), holding a PLACARD that reads “Best Man.” Nick lights up to see them.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Nick!!! Nick!!!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Araminta!

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I missed you, too. Araminta releases Nick and immediately grabs Rachel in a tight hug. Rachel reacts, surprised, amused. Colin grabs Nick in a big bear hug, pulling him back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Colin) Hey.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: COLIN ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: (to Nick) (to Rachel) There he is. How are you? It’s so nice to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK RACHEL
dialogues.text: (to Colin) (to Araminta) I’m good. It’s so nice to meet you, too. Araminta has no makeup on under her spectacles, and is wearing pajama pants, a tank top, and flip-flops. Nick gives Colin a big hug. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Ah! WNicki-Nick! Welcome!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s been too long, brother.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: It has been too long. Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You guys didn’t have to pick us up.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Of course we did. We had to!

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Of course I had to come welcome my best man properly. (to Rachel) Hi, Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hello. They embrace warmly.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Oh! Lovely to finally meet you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, too.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Shall we? Let me help you with this.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Yes. (handing Rachel the balloons) And these are for you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yes! I can grab these. All right.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh! Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: I know they’re a bit over the top. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Let’s get you all localized.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Are you hungry?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I’m always hungry. So let’s eat everything we can.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin pushes the luggage cart out the door, flanked by Rachel, Nick, and Araminta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The open-top SUV flies down the highway. Colin is at the wheel as Nick, Rachel, and Araminta take in the sites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLAMES LEAP over a wok as a CRAB is thrown in. QUICK CUTS OF FOOD: stir-fried clams, turnip cakes, banana leaf rice, laksa soup noodles, ice being shaved over an ice kachang bowl. Rachel stares in wonderment at an endless hive of food stalls underneath swaying palm trees, right on the beach. Even though it is late, the place teems with HUNDREDS of DINERS. All eating with great relish. Nick, Araminta, and Colin move like seasoned locals. Colin scans the seating area, spots a table.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Minty, three o'clock! Araminta hurries over, buys TISSUE PACKETS from an OLD WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN AT MARKET
dialogues.text: (in Mandarin; subtitled) Guam Xia. [Thank you.] (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: (in Mandarin) Guam Xia. (in English) Hey, guys! Here! Araminta tosses a tissue packet to Nick and Rachel. Nick grabs Rachel, kicking off our --

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you. (to Rachel) Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- They walk by the dizzying array of stalls, Nick is excited to share this world with Rachel:

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Each of these hawker stalls sells pretty much one dish, and they've been perfecting it for generations. You know, this is one of the only places in the world where street food vendors actually earn Michelin stars. -- A beaming PRAWN NOODLE SELLER HUGS Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NOODLE SELLER
dialogues.text: Hey! How are you, sir? Long time, no see, my friend. (calls to worker; handing Nick food) Here you go. Thank you very much, sir.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Uncle! Oh. Cheers. -- Colin brings food to a table where Araminta sits, tissue packets holding a place for all of them.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Ooh! Look at this. Look at this.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Oh, my favorite. -- Nick orders from a MALAY SATAY vendor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (in Malay) Sate dua puluh. Sepuluh ayam. Sepuluh daging. [Twenty pieces of satay. Ten chicken satay. Ten beef satay. ]

dialogues.speaker: SAME SCENE
dialogues.text: The table is OVERFLOWING with various dishes.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: There he is. Nice.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Where do you want me to put this? Nick and Rachel go off to order more food.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (in Mandarin) Luxa, liang wan, yi wan buyao lajiang. [Luxa, give me one bowl of that, one of them without spicy sauce. ]

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: Nick hands each of them mug of beer.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: One of those for you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SHAVED ICE VENDOR
dialogues.text: Nick and Rachel ordering shaved ice.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (in Mandarin) Guan Xia.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Looks a little vomity.  30.

dialogues.speaker: AT ANOTHER VENDOR
dialogues.text: Nick is now ordering soup.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE TABLE
dialogues.text: They are finally enjoying all the various dishes.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my God!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yes! I told you! I told you. The best satay on the island. For sure. All right. Araminta and Colin grin with approval.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: All right, dig in, guys.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Oh, really? So yummy, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: (to Nick) Oh, before I forget, I need your help tomorrow. Uh, I need to do some groomsmen stuff and I don’t wanna do it alone with Bernard Tai.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I still cannot believe that you got that guy to be your groomsman.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you. I rest my case.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Minty...

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Well, it wasn’t up to me, was it? It’s not my choice. Bernard is the human douche nozzle who used to steal my tuck shop money when we were kids, until Nicki-Nick beat him up.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You beat somebody up?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hold on -- I threw a single punch. I fell on the floor and the guy sat on me. So, wasn’t really much of a fight.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: (raises glass) A toast, guys. To my best man, Nick Young, who can’t fight for nuts, but will always have your back!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thank you. Colin and Nick continue to laugh and reminisce.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: A toast to married life.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Oh! Not yet! Not yet! Too early.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh! Well, this time next week, guys!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We gotta get over your bachelor party first, matey.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Is that necessary, man? Come on!

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Listen, Rachel, I know we’ve only just met, but it’s my bachelorette party this weekend and I would love for you to come. Rachel is surprised, happy to be embraced by Nick’s pals. Nick and Colin still bantering in the b.g. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COLIN RACHEL
dialogues.text: (to Nick) (to Araminta) Hold on, if I make it out That would be amazing. alive! I would be -- Thank you so much!

dialogues.speaker: NICK ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: That’s gonna be the Good! Good! least...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: If I -- Am I out of the picture?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Am I totally out of the picture?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve replaced you with Bernard.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Well, that --

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Screw that, man. Nick and Colin joke and laugh with each other.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Also, I have to say, I can’t remember the last time I saw Nick like this.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (overlaps) No, that’s funny, though.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: He’s just happy to be home.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: (making a face) Oh, yeah, he’s just happy to be home. With you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (overlaps) I’m sorry. I’m sorry, man. Your dad will be the death of you. We STAY ON Rachel -- she looks at Nick, happy, in his element. He glances at her with that smile -- and she falls that much more in love with him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: My dad will be the death of me. Oh, cheers to that.

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Guys, we have to dig in ‘cause this crab is not gonna eat itself.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Pass me that.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What should I try first? (to Colin) Do you want some of this?

dialogues.speaker: COLIN
dialogues.text: Eat up, eat up! Try some of this. Oh, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It's really spicy.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It is really spicy. Oh, God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them driving down the highway in the open-top SUV enjoying the beautiful city. Nick points to various landmarks with glee. We see a MONTAGE of beautiful fountains, boats going under bridges, etc. The girls, in the back seat, put their arms around their guys’ necks and snuggle.

dialogues.speaker: ARAMINTA
dialogues.text: Whoo! (shouting) Nick’s in Singapore!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s good to be home. INT. ASTRID’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Astrid enters, followed by the porters. The apartment isn’t enormous, but each room is straight out of the pages of Architectural Digest. TWO MAIDS quickly swing into action, taking the bags and unpacking them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Is Michael here?

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: Not yet, ma’am. Also, your son woke up. He wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: All right. You know what to do. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: MAID
dialogues.text: Okay. Put over here. Okay... Move, move. The Maids nod, knowing the drill. The head Maid hides two bags labeled “Dior” and “Lotus - Arts de Vivre” ina drawer. The begin scurrying around the apartment in a frenzy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- One maid puts a small jewelry-sized box tied with a bow in a metal tin and places the lid back on. -- Another maid stashes a small box in a kitchen drawer and covers it with the cloth napkins. -- In the bathroom, Astrid takes off her EARRINGS, puts them back in their original box and places the box above the mirror. INT. ASTRID'S APARTMENT - CASSIAN’S ROOM - NIGHT Astrid lies by her son, CASSIAN (3), who’s half-asleep in bed as she reads The Little Prince to him in French.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: (in perfect French) -- Cette visite fut trés courte, mais elle plongea le petit prince dans une grande mélancolie... Astrid pauses when she hears SOMEONE enter the apartment. She looks to Cassian, now sound asleep, and heads out. INT. ASTRID’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - NIGHT We see a man taking a shower. This is MICHAEL TEO, 30s, Astrid’s husband, former Army Sergeant, and ripped/hot as all hell, exits the bathroom in a towel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He talks to Astrid, who’s on the bed as he dries off and gets ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Got stuck ina meeting.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: It's okay. I get it. But don’t forget, wedding festivities start on Wednesday, so no emergencies next week.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (facetious) I know. Wouldn’t dream of missing a second with your family and their friends.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Come on, it won't be all bad. Nick and his new girlfriend will be there. You'll like her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah? Why? ‘Cause she’s a commoner like me?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: You know that’s not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Oh... You know, I thought I caught the maids trying to shove a pair of Jimmy Choos behind the dryer. (off Astrid kissing his shoulder) Yeah, I don’t know why you bother trying to hide your shopping from me. You can buy whatever you want. I get it. Besides, everybody knows you wear the money pants in this family.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: (whispering) Pants are overrated. (kisses his shoulder; then) Oh, I got you something, too. To celebrate the launch of your startup. I know you don’t like expensive gifts, but you’re not a captain in the Army anymore. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re a CEO. You should look the part. She takes the gift out from under the pillow revealing an expensive men’s watch.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: To celebrate the launch of your startup. I know you don’t like expensive gifts, but you’re not a captain in the Army anymore, you're a CEO. You should look the part.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I -- I love it. Thank you. He KISSES her. She kisses back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. RAFFLES HOTEL - SUITE —- MORNING Radio alarms goes off. It’s playing Marvin Gaye’s “You're All I Need to Get By.” REVEAL Rachel waking up in a luxurious, Colonial suite -- smiles when she remembers where she is. Nick’s arm is around her. She turns to see he’s awake, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Morning. I’m afraid it’s time for me to do some groomsman duties.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Ummmmmmmmmn. .. ~Stay in bed.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You stay here. I’11 get youa breakfast tray. Nick gets out of bed as Rachel lazily sits up, putting her glasses on.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You know, I have to get up, too. I told Peik Lin I would meet up with her today. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Ah, a little college reunion. But don't forget. Dinner at Ah Ma’s tonight.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The whole family’s gonna be there.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I can’t wait to show you off. She moves her glasses back and forth on her nose, in and out as if trying to get a better focus on Nick’s body.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hubba-hubba.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: How can I resist?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Ah. Ooga-ooga. Rachel looks at him lovingly. He comes back for one more kiss.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You put those glasses on on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel exits a taxi wearing the red dress her mother picked. She goes to the gate of a showy mansion. We hear a BUZZER, then the gate opens. We hear another BUZZER and the front door opens. PEIK LIN (29), emerges carrying one of her Pekingese dogs. Peik Lin is half type-A go-getter, half hip-hop, all attitude.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: New York in the house! Yeah! Yeah! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peik Lin rushes to her, as they hug:

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Aw! Peik Lin!

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: What up, bitch? Yeah! Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! You look amazing.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: I know. Some things never change, right?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (re: mansion) And this is q-- quite a place. 38. SIX GOLDEN-HAIRED PEKINGESE DOGS run out, their high- pitched yaps filling the air.

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: Astor! Vanderbilt! Rockefeller! Naughty, naughty boys, stop barking. Hey, Rachel!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hi! NEENAH GOH (50s), Peik Lin’s mother, comes out. A short woman with a bouffant perm. She wears a tight blouse, a belt of interlinked gold Medusa heads, tight trousers, and pink slippers.

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: Singapore is so hot. Come in and enjoy the aircon. Come, come on. Whole family waiting to meet you. Very excited. They head into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neena and Peik Lin show Rachel into the cavernous living room, everything is covered with gold or mirrors. takes it in, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: Rachel, welcome, welcome. Rachel (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Wow! Oh, my gosh! Your house is amazing, Mrs. Goh.

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: (in Hokkien; subtitled) Li gaou kong wei ah. [You're such a sweet talker. ] (in English) Call me Auntie. Auntie Neenah.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Sorry. Auntie Neenah.

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Uh... Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah. We were inspired by the Hall of Mirrors in Versailles.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: (to Rachel; low) And Donald Trump’s bathroom, as well.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: You like it or not?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Uh, the gold is very brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEVEN MEMBERS of the Goh family sit at a long dining table as four maids serve the anything-but-"small” lunch. It’s a free-for-all as everyone reaches for food. It’s a colorful bunch. There’s Peik Lin’s father WYE MUN (50s), and a multitude of children including: P.T. (30s) shy, overweight, TWO ADORABLE TWIN GIRLS who eat CHICKEN NUGGETS from a TAKEOUT BOX on heavy, gold-rimmed Limoges plates, and a BABY in a TRICKED-OUT GOLD BASSINET. Neena waves chopsticks at Rachel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Uh, uh, uh. Rachel Chu, we are so, uh, grateful for all the help you have given my, uh, Peik Lin back in her uni days. I mean, without you, uh, she would be a hot mess. He chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, no. Actually, if it wasn’t for her, I'd be a big mess. She was a huge help to me in college. (beat) It's nice to meet you, Mr. Goh.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, too, uh, Chu. Ku-ku. Ku-Chu. You. Poo-poo. (laughs) No, I’m just kidding. I don’t have an accent. I’m just messing with you. Neenah chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: No, no, I, I studied in the States, too. Yeah, Cal State Fullerton. Yeah. I majored in Thought.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hmm.

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: Don’t stand on ceremony, Rachel. This is simple food, lah.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Ah! Cha-cha-cha. Don’t be shy.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: You're not a model.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I am definitely not. Rachel looks at thirteen different dishes, which look anything but simple. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Wye Mun puts food on Rachel’s plate. Neena feeds her dog with chopsticks sitting in a chair next to her.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: No, you’re not. Not at all. You're far from it.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: And make sure you eat it all. ‘Cause I’m watching you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Okay, thank you. Okay, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TWIN GIRL
dialogues.text: Ah pa, can we go «+. go trampoline. trampoline!

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Ay, you haven’t finished your nuggets yet, sweetie. Okay, there’s a lot of children starving in America, right? I mean, take a look at her. She’s American. Huh? Really skinny. You wanna look like that?

dialogues.speaker: TWIN GIRL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Then eat your nuggets. The girls dutifully return to their food.

dialogues.speaker: NEENA
dialogues.text: So, Rachel, what you do in America?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Um, I’m an economics professor.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: (impressed) Whoa. Very impressive. Econ professor, eh? Wow! You must be very smart. Good for you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: (to Peik Lin) Let me get this straight. You both went to the same school, yet someone came back with a degree that’s useful. And the other came back as Asian Ellen. Peik Lin reacts, grandpa laughs. Wye Mun turns to his son, P.T.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: (nods toward Rachel) Psst. P.T. P.T. Hmm?

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: (nodding toward Rachel) Look over here. She’s a hottie. This is the kind of girl you should date. Smart, beautiful. Not those, like, K-Pop skanks, with, like, no brain, big eyes and small backsides. She has an amazing backside. This is Goh standard. Don’t be shy. Just talk to her. P.T. looks up from his noodles, clueless. P.T. (whispering) I love you.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Okay. No, just, uh...

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Pa, she’s here with her boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: I don’t see no ring on her finger.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, well, my boyfriend’s actually from Singapore and that’s why we're here. We’re here to go to his best friend’s wedding where he’s gonna be the best man.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Hmm. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: What’s his name? This is a very small island. Maybe we know his family.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: His name is Nick Young. The food drops out of Wye Mun’s mouth. The whole table STOPS EATING. Eyes go wide. Jaws drop. Even grandpa and the twins stop what they’re doing and look at Rachel. Rachel becomes self-conscious.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: The Nick you're dating is Nick Young?!

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: (puts it together) His best friend... You’re invited to Colin Khoo'’s wedding, ah?!!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah. You guys know them or something? P.T. snaps a quick pic of Rachel on his cell. He smiles and admires it like it’s the Mona Lisa.

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Hells yeah. The Khoos, the Youngs, I mean, who doesn’t know who they are?! (getting worked up) They’re just the biggest developers in all of Singapore. And Malaysia, Thailand, Brunei, New Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: She gets it. (to Rachel) Colin and Araminta’s wedding is, like, Singapore’s event of the century! The Youngs are like royalty. Wye Mun vigorously shakes his head, “yes.”

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Did you not know? Does she not know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NEENAH
dialogues.text: Why you never say before?! Tell, tell, what are they like?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I don’t really know what they’re -- I, I mean, I haven’t met them yet. I’m gonna meet them tonight. I’m going to Nick’s grandma’s house.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: You're going to Nick’s grandma's house wearing this? (re: Rachel’s dress) Wearing that? They all laugh. P.T. No way. No way.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, I thought red was a lucky color, right?

dialogues.speaker: WYE MUN
dialogues.text: Yeah, if you’re an envelope. Zing! Nailed it! P.T. takes another picture of Rachel, but she waves him

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: TWINS
dialogues.text: Zing zing! Peik Lin looks Rachel up and down, shaking her head disgusted with her outfit. INT. PEIK LIN’S BEDROOM - CLOSET - DAY Peik Lin throws open the doors to her massive walk-in closet. Clothes are color-coded, wrapped in plastic, with a string of POLAROIDS over them showing the different looks. Rachel looks around, in awe.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Rachel, these people aren’t just rich, okay. They’re crazy rich. Peik Lin looks around, pulls out a LARGE HANDBAG with a WORLD MAP on it, which she points to as she explains: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Look, there’s new money all over Asia. We got the Beijing Billionaires, the Taiwan Tycoons. But the Young family, they’re old Money rich. They had money when they left China in the 1800s. And they went all the way down here. Not there. Here. They came to Singapore when there was nothing but jungle and pig farmers. There was a snake here, eating an apple. You know what I mean? And they built all of this. Now, they’re the landlords of the most expensive city in the world. Here you go. (hands Rachel the purse) These people are so posh and snobby, they’re snoshy. Here you go. Peik Lin hands her a pair of platform shoes.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, but Nick’s not like that.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Even if he isn’t, I guarantee you the family is. Which is why tonight, you need to not look like Sebastian of The Little Mermaid. You know, little crab guy. Peik Lin throws her a dress...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AN AUDI SWERVES ERRATICALLY through traffic, brakes squealing, horns honking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel, in an elegant cocktail dress, holds on for dear life as Peik Lin drives like she’s on the Indy circuit.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: (shouting at cars) Come on, this isn’t your grandma's road. God damn it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you for driving me.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Duh. This is, like, my one chance to see the Young family mansion.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Mm. They turn off onto a private road.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE GPS VOICE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At the next intersection, make a U- turn. Make a U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Uh, are you sure you gave me the right address? The GPS says there's, like, nothing here. Like literally nothing. They pull over on a deserted road.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I mean, I -- I put in the exact address. This is --

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: You copied and your pasted it?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Did you just copy and paste ‘jungle’ and just kind of threw it in there?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No, it says this is the address...

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Because I feel like that’s -- You actually used the -- A bearded man wearing a red turban appears at her side window.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: -- Okay. All right. That’s a -- Hi! So we'll just -- (rolls down window just a crack) Hello, sir. How are you? (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’re here for the party, and we're... We come in peace.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Do you know where the Young family house is? Another man appears at Rachel’s window. These are uniformed SIKH GUARDS.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nicholas Young? I’m, I’m Rachel Chu. I’m here to, to go to his family dinner. The one guard carrying a rifle creeps around the car, inspecting it. The other speaks on his walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Uh, Rachel Chu for the list. If there is a list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of nowhere, a MASSIVE GATE looms with TYERSALL PARK written across the top. The gate is closed. The guard on the walkie walks to the gate looking back at Peik Lin and Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: He’s on the phone. He’s on the phone. Is that a gun knife? It’s a knife gun. It’s a -- The other guard now comes around to Peik Lin’s window.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Okay, and there’s a friend. Hi! Very, very nice to -- Guard #1 motions for them to drive forward.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: We can go through? We’re going through? Okay. Don’t stab the car. The gates swing open.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Okay. Thank you. Bye! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As Peik Lin drives through the gates, she and Rachel look around, entranced. STREET LIGHTS/LANTERNS illuminate both sides of the large driveway, which seems to wind endlessly up through a hilly rainforest. Unlike the rest of developed Singapore, it feels old, untouched. Peik Lin has her mouth hanging open, amazed.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my God, it’s beautiful. The forest finally gives way to rolling grounds and an avenue lined with tall palms. A VAST COLONIAL MANSION comes INTO VIEW. This is not a house, it is a palace.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Beautiful? It’s two hundred mil worth of real estate. (almost tearing up) --. It’s spectacular. They drive up to the front of the house. Servants are posted in various locations outside. Two of the servants open the front doors and Nick, in a linen suit and perfectly-tousled hair, walks out. Looking every bit the prince of the manor.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: (awestruck) Damn, Rachel. He’s like the Asian ‘Bachelor.’ Nick walks up to the car and opens Rachel’s door.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hello, gorgeous. He takes her hand as she exits the car. Nick looks at her outfit, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Wow! I think I’ve just fallen in love with you all over again. He kisses her -- Peik Lin clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Missed you, too. Peik Lin keeps clearing her throat, trying to get Rachel’s attention. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What did you get up to?

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: (hisses) Rachel!

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, this is my friend, Peik Lin.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey, there.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Howdy.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thank you very much for bringing Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no worries.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Do you wanna stop by for some dinner?

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Oh, no, I couldn’t impose. It’s a --

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (interrupts) No, it’s not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: You know, I had some dinner plans --

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Seriously, we've got a lot of --

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’1l fucking come to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: It was fun! I got to meet Peik Lin’s whole family, and her dogs. Nick and Rachel continue to chit-chat in the b.g. --

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yeah, and twin sisters. And Peik Lin dressed me. Peik Lin jumps out, pops the trunk, and sorts through several outfits covered in garment bags labeled: “Clubbing,” “Cocktail,” and “Walk of Shame.”

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: (re: “Walk of Shame” ) Nope. She pulls out the COCKTAIL DRESS and a pair of HEELS.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You have a cocktail dress in your trunk?

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: (of course) I’m not an animal, Rachel. As they head in, Rachel and Peik Lin look around at all the guests --

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (to Nick) I thought this was just a family thing.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Grandmother’s invited some of her friends over tonight. Her tan huas are blooming.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It's a whole thing. You ready for this? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Rachel nods. Servants open the doors. Holding her hand, they enter:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chanteuse JASMINE CHEN, backed by a JAZZ BAND, sings a Chinese number as Rachel, Nick, and Peik Lin enter.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Oh, damn, Nick. It’s a party, though. Okay. Many guests mingle and talk in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN IN RED FLOWER DRESS WOMAN IN BLUE DRESS
dialogues.text: (to women) Hi. Yes. Hello. Mrs... Mrs...

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Peik Lin) The good bathrooms are up the stairs, and you can get changed in there.

dialogues.speaker: PEIK LIN
dialogues.text: Okay, good, I’ll find it. Thank you. Peik Lin climbs the stairs, then stops to take a SELFIE, climbs a few more stairs, and takes another SELFIE.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: You know, when you said you grew up in your grandma’s house, I wasn’t expecting this. A waiter approaches carrying finger bowls with flowers floating in them. Rachel thinks they are drinks and begins to bring one to her mouth --

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (to waiter) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh, no, no, no. Those are for your fingers. (to server) Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Uh, a little bit much, I know.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I mean, this place is gorgeous. And like the rolling green hills. I mean, there are armed guards out there. Rachel is looking at A STUFFED TIGER, mouth open, about to pounce. Nick laugh

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: And a giant tiger. Ss.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Now, that is Mr. Harimau. Now, my great-grandfather actually shot him when he ran into the house. But Astrid and I, we used to hide cigarettes in his paws.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Do you wanna head in?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Actually, I wanted to bring you over to my mum first.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DISTANT JAZZ RIFF CONTINUES as we ENTER a bustling scene with MAIDS plating food, choppers chopping veggies madly, COOKS working over WOKS that BURST INTO FLAME, CHILDREN s neaking snacks. Amidst it all is Eleanor in Carolina Herrera, presiding over everything. She inspects various dishes, dispatching orders with calm authority: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (in Cantonese; subtitled) Qie de you xi di, mi bao de han hou, di zhu wu hao tai. Fang lajiao... Shi fenzhong hao la. [Cut it thinner. Don’t wrap it too thick. Watch it, don’t make it too soft. Add chili... Ten minutes only. ] She's clearly used to running a great house and being obeyed. She pauses when she sees Nick enter. She’s delighted, but keeps her composure. Nick gives his mother a peck on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Mum. Eleanor affectionately touches his hair.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: You need a haircut. So unkempt. (concerned) And you look tired from your trip. I’m gonna ask the cook to make you some herbal soup. (in Cantonese to cook) Dun di jitang bi shaoye. (to Nick) I’ll send it to the hotel later. Eleanor sees Rachel.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Mum, this is Rachel Chu.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my gosh! I, I’m so happy to meet you, Mrs. Young. (gives her a big hug) Or, uh, Auntie. Right? (giggles) I’m learning the lingo. Eleanor smiles, subtly scans Rachel, evaluating her.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: I’m very glad to finally meet you, too. And I’m sorry Nick’s father couldn’t be here. He was called to business in Shanghai. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I told Rachel when duty calls, Dad answers.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: As it should be. (to Rachel) Nick tells me you’re a professor, too. What do you teach?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Um, I teach Economics.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And she’s brilliant. NYU’s youngest faculty member. To Nick and Rachel’s surprise, Eleanor suddenly leaves the conversation to inspect a tray of hors d’oeuvres. She fixes the tray and then returns.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (to cooks; in Cantonese; subtitled) Wu hao luo ge ge, lingwai. [Don’t take that one. Another one. ] (back to Nick and Rachel) So, economics. Sounds challenging. (subtly fishing) Are your parents academics, as well?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Uh, no. Well, my dad actually died before I was born and, um, my mom didn’t even go to college. She actually hardly spoke any English when she immigrated to the United States.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: (in Cantonese; to cook; subtitled) Fang di yan qian xi ge du. [Put some cilantro there. ]

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: But she worked really hard, and she studied, and she earned her real estate license while she was waiting tables to support us. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now, she likes to say that she’s Flushing’s top real estate broker. Nick glances at his mother, gauging her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Self-made woman. She must be so proud of you. Eleanor continues fiddling and fussing with the table, inspecting the food, coldly turning her back on the couple.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Well, she knows that I’m passionate about what I do, and she’s always wanted that for me.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Pursuing one’s passions. How American. Well, your mother is very open-minded, not like here, where parents are obsessed with shaping the life of their children. It sounds like a compliment, but Rachel isn’t entirely sure. Eleanor turns away again to talk to a passing COOK before returning to Rachel: Eleanor shoots Nick a look. He shifts, uncomfortable, and is relieved to hear a MUSICAL GONG from upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hmm. Oh. That’s dinner.

dialogues.speaker: ELEANOR
dialogues.text: Hmm. Go ahead. I’11 be out ina minute. Rachel, it was lovely meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. You, too. Rachel smiles as she and Nick head off.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Okay, she hates me.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (optimistic) She takes a little minute to warm up, but we’ll get there. OFF Eleanor, watching Rachel leave...  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rachel and Nick enter. She is stunned. The expansive “living room” looks more like a glamorous club in Shanghai. DOZENS of impeccably-dressed, bejeweled GUESTS cluster in seating areas. A buffet is STACKED with gorgeous dishes and desserts.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nicki!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Astrid.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Rachel!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey, good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: I’m so glad you could make it. As we GO TO different tableaus and conversations, CAMERA DANCES ALONG, giving the feel of a choreographed number. Astrid, in a perfect cocktail dress, heads for them, followed by Michael. She hugs Nick and Rachel, delighted.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Michael.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Astrid! So good to see a face I know.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nick.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: This is my husband, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. Heard so much about you.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you, Michael. Eddie barrels in, smacks Nick too hard on the back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hey, the golden boy’s back! Nick! (to Rachel) And you must be Rachel. I’m Edison Cheng. This is my wife.

dialogues.speaker: FIONA
dialogues.text: HI, I’m Fi--

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Her name is Fiona. So, I see you've already met Princess Astrid and her little soldier toy-boy, Mikey. (busts Michael’s balls) You know Mikey is a big-shot tech startup guy. So if you, uh, forget your password, he’s your man. (then) So, you're from the Taiwan plastic Chus, right?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, well, actually... As Eddie commandeers Rachel, Michael has an aside with Nick. Astrid goe

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Can I punch him in the face? Just once.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Take a number.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: I‘1ll be in my usual corner. (to Astrid) Champagne?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Thank you. s over to Nick.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: So, have you prepped Rachel to face the wolves?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Rachel is a New Yorker, and she lectures Millennials for a living. I think she can manage our family. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Astrid looks at Nick like he’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: You've been away too long.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Okay, sorry, time out. So, you’re not from a Taiwan Chu family?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Hong Kong telecom Chus?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Malaysian packing peanut Chus?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Is that really a thing?

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s everywhere. You just -- Before Eddie can continue, Nick cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m gonna stop you there because I’m gonna take her on the rounds. We’ll be back, though. As Nick and Rachel leave, Eddie calls after.

dialogues.speaker: EDDIE
dialogues.text: No, wait. Hang on. China instant noodle Chus. Rachel... (as Rachel turns) Chu are you? (to Fiona) Let's go. Eddie laughs hysterically at his own horrible joke. Rachel politely smiles and moves on. Francesca and Celine hover nearby to listen in and get the dirt on Rachel.  59.

dialogues.speaker: PARTY SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: The jazz band breaks into a DRUM SECTION as Nick introduces his family to Rachel, who’s anxious to make a good impression. CAMERA DOES 360 LOOPS AROUND them, REVEALING a new set of people each time:

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: This is Auntie Alix and Auntie Felicity.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Hi! It’s so nice to meet you. I’ve never been to a tan hua party before.

dialogues.speaker: FELICITY
dialogues.text: We love any excuse to throw a soirée. Do your parents like to entertain? Oh! I’m sorry. Your mother’s single. Alix shoots Felicity a “don’t be insensitive” look.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Yup. OFF Rachel, amused, realizing word has gotten around.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Auntie Jacqueline. One of my parents’ oldest friends.

dialogues.speaker: JACQUELINE
dialogues.text: I actually met Nick’s father at Cambridge. (fishing) So, what line of work is your father in?

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my father died before I was born. But he was a factory worker in China. Jacqueline slurps her wine loudly to drown out the horror on her face. In the b.g. Francesca and Celine overhear, smirk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: -- An OLDER CHINESE LADY (60s) in traditional Chinese dress, speaks to Nick, happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: LING CHEH, (OLDER CHINESE LADY)
dialogues.text: (to Nick; in Mandarin; subtitled) Nicki a, shi ni nv pengyou a? Yao gankuai jiehun luo, a? [Nicki, is this your girlfriend? You should hurry up and get married, okay?] Nick laughs. Rachel smiles, assumes she’s Nick’s grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: (in Mandarin; subtitled) Ah Ma, xiexie nin yaoquing wo lai nin de jia. Zheli hao piaoliang. (Grandma, thank you for inviting me to your home. It’s very beautiful. ] The Older Lady looks at Rachel, confused.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (low; to Rachel) This is Ling Cheh, my old nanny. Rachel is mortified. Francesca and Celine laugh in the b.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Astrid holds a covered plate, looks for Michael. She sees him in the corner of the library, on his phone:

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (into phone) Look, now’s the time we need all hands on deck. Please, please, just do me this favor. Thank you. Bye-bye. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: They started clearing away dinner. Astrid hands him the plate.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Your favorites. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Michael takes the plate, kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: You know, if you need bodies at the office, I could always come in and help out.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (playfully) The glamorous Astrid Leong working as an assistant?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: (realizing) Wait, isn’t Araminta’s bachelorette party tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: And this would be the perfect excuse to get out of it.

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Really. But I’ve got everything covered.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Okay. (beat) I forgot to get you a fork. Um...

dialogues.speaker: MICHAEL
dialogues.text: It’s okay, you stay. I’1l go get it. He winks at her and takes off. Astrid smiles as she watches him go. She hears a BUZZ from his phone which he’s left on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: ASTRID
dialogues.text: Michael, I think it’s the office! But Michael doesn’t hear her. He’s gone. There’s a PING and a text pops up. She glances at the screen: TEXT: The bed feels empty without you. Astrid is stricken. Astrid drops the phone, her world caving in.  62.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE PARTY
dialogues.text: Jacqueline and others in the b.g. subtly clock this. A dapper man, OLIVER T’SIEN (30s), looks on with interest.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! Nick, I can’t believe I just did that.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It's fine. I don’t think anybody even noticed.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL
dialogues.text: I think I freaked out your nanny -- She spills her drink down the front of Nick’s shirt.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Oh! My God!
